author: pauld.9606
content: On modern hardware, subroutines are implemented by pushing the return address to the operand stack, then jumping.

author: pauld.9606
content: Interestingly, ARM (optional) and RISC-V (required) have jump opcodes which designate a link register to which it saves the return address (next opcode) to. This allows skipping the stack. But I am guessing that most calling conventions will use the stack anyway, since the link register will be clobbered by subsequent jumps.

author: pauld.9606
content: The RISC-V manual says "Return-address prediction stacks are a common feature of high-performance instruction-fetch units." So an optional second stack is useful in hardware instruction fetch.
